Unbalanced Optimal Transport: A Unified Framework for Object Detection

Henri De Plaen1*  Pierre-François De Plaen2*  Johan A. K. Suykens1  Marc Proesmans2
Tinne Tuytelaars2  Luc Van Gool2,3
1ESAT-STADIUS, KU Leuven, Belgium  2ESAT-PSI, KU Leuven, Belgium
3Computer Vision Lab, ETH Zürich, Switzerland
Abstract

During training, supervised object detection tries to correctly match the predicted bounding boxes and associated classification scores to the ground truth. This is essential to determine which predictions are to be pushed towards which solutions, or to be discarded. Popular matching strategies include matching to the closest ground truth box (mostly used in combination with anchors), or matching via the Hungarian algorithm (mostly used in anchor-free methods). Each of these strategies comes with its own properties, underlying losses, and heuristics. We show how Unbalanced Optimal Transport unifies these different approaches and opens a whole continuum of methods in between. This allows for a finer selection of the desired properties. Experimentally, we show that training an object detection model with Unbalanced Optimal Transport is able to reach the state-of-the-art both in terms of Average Precision and Average Recall as well as to provide a faster initial convergence. The approach is well suited for GPU implementation, which proves to be an advantage for large-scale models.

{NoHyper}**footnotetext: These authors contributed equally.

1 Introduction

Object detection models are in essence multi-task models, having to both localize objects in an image and classify them. In the context of supervised learning, each of these tasks heavily depends on a matching strategy. Indeed, determining which predicted object matches which ground truth object is a non-trivial yet essential task during the training (Figure 1(a)). In particular, the matching strategy must ensure that there is ideally exactly one prediction per ground truth object, at least during inference. Various strategies have emerged, often relying on hand-crafted components. They are proposed as scattered approaches that seem to have nothing in common, at least at first glance.

1.1 A Unifying Framework

To perform any match, a matching cost has to be determined. The example at Fig. 1(b) uses the Generalized Intersection over Union (GIoUGIoU\mathrm{GIoU}) [giou]. Given such a cost matrix, matching strategies include:

  • •

    Matching each prediction to the closest ground truth object. This often requires that the cost lies under a certain threshold [liu2016ssd, ren2015fasterrcnn, redmon2016yolo, lin2017focalloss], to avoid matching predictions that may be totally irrelevant for the current image. The disadvantage of this strategy is its redundancy: many predictions may point towards the same ground truth object. In Fig. 1(c), both predictions 1 and 4 are matched towards ground truth object A. Furthermore, some ground truth objects may be unmatched. A solution to this is to increase the number of predicted boxes drastically. This is typically the case with anchors boxes and region proposal methods.

  • •

    The opposite strategy is to match each ground truth object to the best prediction [he2015spatial, liu2016ssd]. This ensures that there is no redundancy and every ground truth object is matched. This also comes with the opposite problem: multiple ground truth objects may be matched to the same prediction. In Fig. 1(e), both ground truth objects A and B are matched to prediction 4. This can be mitigated by having more predictions, but then many of those are left unmatched, slowing convergence [liu2016ssd].

  • •

    A compromise is to perform a Bipartite Matching (BM), using the Hungarian algorithm [kuhn1955hungarian, munkres1957algorithmstransportationhungarian], for example [carion2020detr, zhu2020deformabledetr]. The matching is one-to-one, minimizing the total cost (Definition 2). Every ground truth object is matched to a unique prediction, thus reducing the number of predictions needed, as shown in Fig. 1(d). A downside is that the one-to-one matches may vary from one epoch to the next, again slowing down convergence [li2022dndetr]. This strategy is difficult to parallelize, i.e. to take advantage of GPU architectures.

All of these strategies have different properties and it seems that one must choose either one or the other, optionally combining them using savant heuristics [liu2016ssd]. There is a need for a unifying framework. As we show in this paper, Unbalanced Optimal Transport[chizat2018unbalanced] offers a good candidate for this (Figure 1). It not only unifies the different strategies here above, but also allows to explore all cases in between. The cases presented in Figures 1(c), 1(d) and 1(e) correspond to the limit cases. This opens the door for all intermediate settings. Furthermore, we show how regularizing the problem induces smoother matches, leading to faster convergence of DETR, avoiding the problem described for the BM. In addition, the particular choice of entropic regularization leads to a class of fast parallelizable algorithms on GPU known as scaling algorithms [cuturi2013sinkhorn, chizat2018scaling], of which we provide a compiled implementation on GPU. Our code and additional resources are publicly available111https://hdeplaen.github.io/uotod.

1.2 Related Work

Matching Strategies  Most two-stage models often rely on a huge number of initial predictions, which is then progressively reduced in the region proposal stage and refined in the classification stage. Many different strategies have been proposed for the initial propositions and subsequent reductions, ranging from training no deep learning networks [girshick2014rcnn], to only train those for the propositions [girshick2015fast, lin2017feature, he2015spatial], to training networks for both propositions and reductions [ren2015fasterrcnn, pang2019libra, he2017maskrcnn, cai2018cascade, dai2016r]. Whenever a deep learning network is trained, each prediction is matched to the closest ground truth object provided it lies beneath a certain threshold. Moreover, the final performance of these models heavily depends on the hand-crafted anchors [liu2020objectdetectionsurvey].

Many one-stage models rely again on predicting a large number of initial predictions or anchor boxes, covering the entire image. As before, each anchor box is matched towards the closest ground truth object with certain threshold constraints [redmon2016yolo, lin2017focalloss]. In [liu2016ssd], this is combined with matching each ground truth object to the closest anchor box and a specific ratio heuristic between the matched and unmatched predictions. The matching of the fixed anchors is justified to avoid a collapse of the predictions towards the same ground truth objects. Additionally, this only works if the number of initial predictions is sufficiently large to ensure that every ground truth object is matched by at least one prediction. Therefore, it requires further heuristics, such as Non-Maximal Suppression (NMS) to guarantee a unique prediction per ground truth object, at least during the inference.

By using the Hungarian algorithm, DETR [carion2020detr] removed the need for a high number of initial predictions. The matched predictions are improved with a multi-task loss, and the remaining predictions are trained to predict the background class ∅\varnothing. Yet, the model converges slowly due to the instability of BM, causing inconsistent optimization goals at early training stages [li2022dndetr]. Moreover, the sequential nature of the Hungarian algorithm does not take full advantage of the GPU architecture. Several subsequent works accelerate the convergence of DETR by improving the architecture of the model [zhu2020deformabledetr, liu2021dabdetr] and by adding auxiliary losses [li2022dndetr], but not by exploring the matching procedure.

Optimal Transport  The theory of Optimal Transport (OT) emerges from an old problem [monge1781memoire], relaxed by a newer formulation [kantorovich]. It gained interest in the machine learning community since the re-discovery of Sinkhorn’s algorithm [cuturi2013sinkhorn] and opened the door for improvements in a wide variety of applications ranging from graphical models [montavon2016wasserstein], kernel methods [kolouri2016sliced, de2020wasserstein], loss design [frogner2015learningwasserstein], auto-encoders [tolstikhin2017wasserstein, kolouri2018sliced, rubenstein2018latent] or generative adversarial networks [arjovsky2017wasserstein, gulrajani2017improved].

More recent incursions in computer vision have been attempted, e.g. for the matching of predicted classes [Han_2020_CVPR_Workshops], a loss for rotated object boxes [pmlr-v139-yang21l] or a new metric for performance evaluation [otani2022optimal]. Considering the matching of predictions to ground truth objects, recent attempts using OT bare promising results [ge2021ota, ge2021yolox]. However, when the Hungarian algorithm is mentioned, it is systematically presented in opposition to OT [ge2021ota, vo2022review]. We lay a rigorous connection between those two approaches in computer vision.

Unbalanced OT has seen a much more recent theoretical development [chizat2018unbalanced, chizat-these]. The hard mass conservation constraints in the objective function are replaced by soft penalization terms. Its applications are scarcer, but we must mention here relatively recent machine learning applications in motion tracking [9152115] and domain adaptation [fatras2021unbalanced].

1.3 Contributions

  1. 1.

    We propose a unifying matching framework based on Unbalanced Optimal Transport. It encompasses both the Hungarian algorithm, the matching of the predictions to the closest ground truth boxes and the ground truth boxes to the closest predictions;

  2. 2.

    We show that these three strategies correspond to particular limit cases and we subsequently present a much broader class of strategies with varying properties;

  3. 3.

    We demonstrate how entropic regularization can speed up the convergence during training and additionally take advantage of GPU architectures;

  4. 4.

    We justify the relevancy of our framework by exploring its interaction with NMS and illustrate how it is on par with the state-of-the-art.

2 Optimal Transport

In this section, we show how Optimal Transport and then its Unbalanced extension unify both the Hungarian algorithm used in DETR [carion2020detr], and matching each prediction to the closest ground truth object used in both Faster R-CNN [ren2015fasterrcnn] and SSD [liu2016ssd]. We furthermore stress the advantages of entropic regularization, both computationally and qualitatively. This allows us to explore a new continuum of matching methods, with varying properties.

Definition 1 (Optimal Transport).

Given a distribution 𝛂∈ΔNp𝛂superscriptΔsubscript𝑁𝑝\bm{\alpha}\in\Delta^{N_{p}} associated to the predictions {𝐲^i}i=1Npsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript^𝐲𝑖𝑖1subscript𝑁𝑝\{\hat{\bm{y}}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{N_{p}}, and another distribution 𝛃∈ΔNg𝛃superscriptΔsubscript𝑁𝑔\bm{\beta}\in\Delta^{N_{g}} associated with the ground truth objects {𝐲j}j=1Ngsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐲𝑗𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑔\{\bm{y}_{j}\}_{j=1}^{N_{g}}. Let us consider a pair-wise matching cost ℒmatch​(𝐲^i,𝐲j)subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝐲𝑖subscript𝐲𝑗\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}) between a prediction 𝐲^isubscript^𝐲𝑖\hat{\bm{y}}_{i} and a ground truth object 𝐲jsubscript𝐲𝑗\bm{y}_{j}. We now define Optimal Transport (OT) as finding the match 𝐏𝐏\bm{P} that minimizes the following problem:

𝑷^=arg​min𝑷∈𝒰​(𝜶,𝜷)​{∑i,j=1Np,NgPi,j​ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚j)},^𝑷𝑷𝒰𝜶𝜷argminsuperscriptsubscript𝑖𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗\hat{\bm{P}}=\underset{\bm{P}\,\in\,\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta})}{\mathrm{arg\,min}}\left\{\sum_{i,j=1}^{N_{p},N_{g}}P_{i,j}\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right\}, (1)

with transport polytope (admissible solutions) 𝒰​(𝛂,𝛃)={𝐏∈ℝ≥0Np×Ng:∑j=1NgPi,j=αi,∑i=1NpPi,j=βj}.𝒰𝛂𝛃conditional-set𝐏superscriptsubscriptℝabsent0subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑔subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗subscript𝛼𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗subscript𝛽𝑗\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta})=\left\{\bm{P}\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}^{N_{p}\times N_{g}}:\sum_{j=1}^{N_{g}}P_{i,j}=\alpha_{i},\sum_{i=1}^{N_{p}}P_{i,j}=\beta_{j}\right\}.

Provided that certain conditions apply to the underlying cost ℒmatchsubscriptℒmatch\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}, the minimum defines a distance between 𝜶𝜶\bm{\alpha} and 𝜷𝜷\bm{\beta}, referred to as the Wasserstein distance 𝒲​(𝜶,𝜷)𝒲𝜶𝜷\mathcal{W}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta}) (for more information, we refer to monographs [villani2009optimal, santambrogio, peyre2019computational]; see also Appendix A.2).

2.1 The Hungarian Algorithm

The Hungarian algorithm solves the Bipartite Matching (BM). We will now show how this is a particular case of Optimal Transport.

Definition 2 (Bipartite Matching).

Given the same objects as in Definition  1, the Bipartite Matching (BM) minimizes the cost of the pairwise matches between the ground truth objects with the predictions:

σ^=argmin{∑j=1Ngℒmatch(𝒚^σ​(j),𝒚j):σ∈𝒫Ng(⟦Np⟧)},\hat{\sigma}=\mathrm{arg\,min}\left\{\sum_{j=1}^{N_{g}}\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{\sigma(j)},\bm{y}_{j}\right):\sigma\in\mathcal{P}_{N_{g}}(\llbracket N_{p}\rrbracket)\right\}, (2)

where 𝒫Ng(⟦Np⟧)={σ∈𝒫(⟦Np⟧)||σ|=Ng}\mathcal{P}_{N_{g}}(\llbracket N_{p}\rrbracket)=\left.\big{\{}\sigma\in\mathcal{P}(\llbracket N_{p}\rrbracket)\,\right||\sigma|=N_{g}\big{\}} is the set of possible combinations of Ngsubscript𝑁𝑔N_{g} in Npsubscript𝑁𝑝N_{p}, with 𝒫(⟦Np⟧)\mathcal{P}(\llbracket N_{p}\rrbracket) the power set of ⟦Np⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝑁𝑝\llbracket N_{p}\rrbracket (the set of all subsets).

BM tries to assign each ground truth 𝒚jsubscript𝒚𝑗\bm{y}_{j} to a different prediction 𝒚^isubscript^𝒚𝑖\hat{\bm{y}}_{i} in a way to minimize the total cost. In contrast to OT, BM does not consider any underlying distributions 𝜶𝜶\bm{\alpha} and 𝜷𝜷\bm{\beta}, all ground truth objects and predictions are implicitly considered to be of same mass. Furthermore, it only allows one ground truth to be matched to a unique prediction, some of these predictions being left aside and matched to nothing (which is then treated as a matching to the background ∅\varnothing). The OT must match all ground truth objects to all predictions, not allowing any predictions to be left aside. However, the masses of the ground truth objects are allowed to be split between different predictions and inversely, as long as their masses correctly sum up (𝑷∈𝒰​(𝜶,𝜷)𝑷𝒰𝜶𝜷\bm{P}\in\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta})).

Particular Case of OT  A solution for an imbalanced number of predictions compared to the number of ground truth objects would be to add dummy ground truth objects—the background ∅\varnothing—to even the balance. Concretely, one could add a new ground truth 𝒚Ng+1=∅subscript𝒚subscript𝑁𝑔1\bm{y}_{N_{g}+1}=\varnothing, with the mass equal to the unmatched number of predictions. In fact, doing so directly results in performing a BM.

Proposition 1.

The Hungarian algorithm with Npsubscript𝑁𝑝N_{p} predictions and Ng≤Npsubscript𝑁𝑔subscript𝑁𝑝N_{g}\leq N_{p} ground truth objects is a particular case of OT with 𝐏∈𝒰​(𝛂,𝛃)⊂ℝNp×(Ng+1)𝐏𝒰𝛂𝛃superscriptℝsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1\bm{P}\in\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta})\subset\mathbb{R}^{N_{p}\times(N_{g}+1)}, consisting of the predictions and the ground truth objects, with the background added {𝐲j}j=1Ng+1={𝐲j}j=1Ng∪(𝐲Ng+1=∅)superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐲𝑗𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑔1superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐲𝑗𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑔subscript𝐲subscript𝑁𝑔1\left\{\bm{y}_{j}\right\}_{j=1}^{N_{g}+1}=\left\{\bm{y}_{j}\right\}_{j=1}^{N_{g}}\cup\left(\bm{y}_{N_{g}+1}=\varnothing\right). The chosen underlying distributions are

𝜶𝜶\displaystyle\bm{\alpha} =\displaystyle= 1Np​[1, 1, 1,…, 1⏟Np predictions],1subscript𝑁𝑝delimited-[]subscript⏟111…1Np predictions\displaystyle\frac{1}{N_{p}}[\;\underbrace{1,\;1,\;1,\;\ldots,\;1}_{\text{$N_{p}$ predictions}}\;], (3)
𝜷𝜷\displaystyle\bm{\beta} =\displaystyle= 1Np​[1, 1,…, 1⏟Ng ground truth objects,(Np−Ng)⏟background ​∅],1subscript𝑁𝑝subscript⏟11…1Ng ground truth objectssubscript⏟subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔background \displaystyle\frac{1}{N_{p}}[\;\underbrace{1,\;1,\;\ldots,\;1}_{\text{$N_{g}$ ground truth objects}},\;\underbrace{(N_{p}-N_{g})}_{\text{background }\varnothing}\;], (4)

provided the background cost is constant: ℒmatch​(𝐲^i,∅)=c∅subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝐲𝑖subscript𝑐\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\varnothing\right)=c_{\varnothing}. In particular for j∈⟦Ng⟧j\in\llbracket N_{g}\rrbracket, we have σ^​(j)={i:Pi,j≠0}^𝜎𝑗conditional-set𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗0\hat{\sigma}(j)=\left\{i:P_{i,j}\neq 0\right\}, or equivalently σ^​(j)={i:Pi,j=1/Np}^𝜎𝑗conditional-set𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑝\hat{\sigma}(j)=\left\{i:P_{i,j}=1/N_{p}\right\}.

Proof.

We refer to Appendix B.1. ∎

In other words, we can read the matching to each ground truth in the columns of 𝑷^^𝑷\hat{\bm{P}}. The last columns represents all the predictions matched to the background σ^​(Ng+1)^𝜎subscript𝑁𝑔1\hat{\sigma}(N_{g}+1). Alternatively and equivalently, we can read the matching of each prediction i𝑖i in the rows, the ones being matched to the background have a P^i,Ng+1=1/Npsubscript^𝑃𝑖subscript𝑁𝑔11subscript𝑁𝑝\hat{P}_{i,N_{g}+1}=1/N_{p}.

Solving the Problem  Both OT and BM are linear programs. Using generic formulations would lead to a (Np+Ng+1)×Np​(Ng+1)subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1\left(N_{p}+N_{g}+1\right)\times N_{p}\left(N_{g}+1\right) equality constraint matrix. It is thus better to exploit the particular bipartite structure of the problem. In particular, two families of algorithms have emerged: Dual Ascent Methods and Auction Algorithms [peyre2019computational]. The Hungarian algorithm is a particular case of the former and classically runs with an 𝒪​(Np4)𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑝4\mathcal{O}\left(N_{p}^{4}\right) complexity [munkres1957algorithmstransportationhungarian], further reduced to cubic by [hungarian-cubic]. Although multiple GPU implementations of a BM solver have been proposed [gpu-bipartite, gpu-hungarian, gpu-matching], the problem remains poorly parallelizable because of its sequential nature. To allow for efficient parallelization, we must consider a slightly amended problem.

2.2 Regularization

We show here how we can replace the Hungarian algorithm by a class of algorithms well-suited for parallelization, obtained by adding an entropy regularization.

Definition 3 (OT with regularization).

We consider a regularization parameter ϵ∈ℝ≥0italic-ϵsubscriptℝabsent0\epsilon\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}. Extending Definition 1 (OT), we define the Optimal Transport with regularization as the following minimization problem:

𝑷^=arg​min𝑷∈𝒰​(𝜶,𝜷)​{∑i,j=1Np,NgPi,j​ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚j)−ϵ​H​(𝑷)},^𝑷𝑷𝒰𝜶𝜷argminsuperscriptsubscript𝑖𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗italic-ϵH𝑷\hat{\bm{P}}=\underset{\bm{P}\,\in\,\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta})}{\mathrm{arg\,min}}\left\{\sum_{i,j=1}^{N_{p},N_{g}}P_{i,j}\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)-\epsilon\,\mathrm{H}(\bm{P})\right\}, (5)

with H:ΔN×M→ℝ≥0:𝐏↦−∑i,jPi,j​(log⁡(Pi,j)−1):H→superscriptΔ𝑁𝑀subscriptℝabsent0:maps-to𝐏subscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗1\mathrm{H}:\Delta^{N\times M}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}:\bm{P}\mapsto-\sum_{i,j}P_{i,j}(\log(P_{i,j})-1) the entropy of the match 𝐏𝐏\bm{P}, with 0​ln⁡(0)=00000\ln(0)=0 by definition.

Sinkhorn’s Algorithm  The entropic regularization used when finding the match 𝑷^^𝑷\hat{\bm{P}} ensures that the problem is smooth for ϵ≠0italic-ϵ0\epsilon\neq 0 (see Figure 3). The advantage is that it can now be solved very efficiently using scaling algorithms and in this particular case the algorithm of Sinkhorn. It is particularly suited for parallelization [cuturi2013sinkhorn], with some later speed refinements [greenkorn, screenkorn]. Reducing the regularization progressively renders the scaling algorithms numerically unstable, although some approaches have been proposed to reduce the regularization further by working in log-space [schmitzer2019stabilized, chizat2018scaling]. In the limit of ϵ→0→italic-ϵ0\epsilon\rightarrow 0, we recover the exact OT (Definition 1) and the scaling algorithms cannot be used anymore. Parallelization is lost and we must resolve to use the sequential algorithms developed in Section 1. In brief, regularization allows to exploit GPU architectures efficiently, whereas the Hungarian algorithm and similar cannot.

Smoother Matches  When no regularization is used as in the Hungarian algorithm, close predictions and ground truth objects can exchange their matches from one epoch to the other, during the training. This causes a slow convergence of DETR in the early stages of the training [li2022dndetr]. The advantage of the regularization not only lies in the existence of efficient algorithms but also allows for a reduction of sparsity. This results in a less drastic match than the Hungarian algorithm obtains. A single ground truth could be matched to multiple predictions and inversely. The proportion of these multiple matches is controlled by the regularization parameter ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. An illustration can be found in Figures 2(a) and 2(b).

2.3 Unbalanced Optimal Transport

We will now show how considering soft constraints instead of hard leads to an even greater generalization of the various matching techniques used in object detection models. In particular, matching each prediction to the closest ground truth is a limit case of the Unbalanced OT.

Definition 4 (Unbalanced OT).

We consider two constraint parameters τ1,τ2∈ℝ≥0subscript𝜏1subscript𝜏2subscriptℝabsent0\tau_{1},\tau_{2}\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}. Extending Definition 3 (OT with regularization), we define the Unbalanced OT with regularization [chizat2018scaling] as the following minimization problem:

𝑷^=arg​min𝑷∈ℝ≥0Np×Ng{ϵKL(𝑷∥𝑲ϵ)+\displaystyle\hat{\bm{P}}=\underset{\bm{P}\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}^{N_{p}\times N_{g}}}{\mathrm{arg\,min}}\biggl{\{}\epsilon\,\mathrm{KL}(\bm{P}\,\|\,\bm{K}_{\epsilon})\,+ τ1​KL​(𝑷​𝟏Ng∥𝜶)subscript𝜏1KLconditional𝑷subscript1subscript𝑁𝑔𝜶\displaystyle\,\tau_{1}\mathrm{KL}(\bm{P}\bm{1}_{N_{g}}\,\|\,\bm{\alpha}) (6)
+\displaystyle+ τ2KL(𝟏Np⊤𝑷∥𝜷)},\displaystyle\,\tau_{2}\mathrm{KL}(\bm{1}_{N_{p}}^{\top}\bm{P}\,\|\,\bm{\beta})\biggr{\}},

where KL:ℝ≥0N×M×ℝ>0N×M→ℝ≥0:(𝐔,𝐕)↦∑i,j=1N×MUi,j​log⁡(Ui,j/Vi,j)−Ui,j+Vi,j:KL→subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑁𝑀absent0subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑁𝑀absent0superscriptsubscriptℝabsent0absent:maps-to𝐔𝐕superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑗1𝑁𝑀subscript𝑈𝑖𝑗subscript𝑈𝑖𝑗subscript𝑉𝑖𝑗subscript𝑈𝑖𝑗subscript𝑉𝑖𝑗\mathrm{KL}:\mathbb{R}^{N\times M}_{\geq 0}\times\mathbb{R}^{N\times M}_{>0}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}^{\phantom{N}}:(\bm{U},\bm{V})\mapsto\sum_{i,j=1}^{N\times M}U_{i,j}\log(U_{i,j}/V_{i,j})-U_{i,j}+V_{i,j} is the Kullback-Leibler divergence – also called relative entropy – between matrices or vectors when M=1𝑀1M=1, with 0​ln⁡(0)=00000\ln(0)=0 by definition. The Gibbs kernel 𝐊ϵsubscript𝐊italic-ϵ\bm{K}_{\epsilon} is given by (Kϵ)i,j=exp⁡(−ℒmatch​(𝐲^i,𝐲j)/ϵ)subscriptsubscript𝐾italic-ϵ𝑖𝑗subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝐲𝑖subscript𝐲𝑗italic-ϵ\left(K_{\epsilon}\right)_{i,j}=\exp\left(-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)/\epsilon\right).

We can see by development that the first term corresponds to the matching term 𝑷​ℒmatch𝑷subscriptℒmatch\bm{P}\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}} and an extension of the entropic regularization term H​(𝑷)H𝑷\mathrm{H}(\bm{P}). The two additional terms replace the transport polytope’s hard constraints 𝒰​(𝜶,𝜷)𝒰𝜶𝜷\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta}) that required an exact equality of mass for both marginals. These new soft constraints allow for a more subtle sensitivity to the mass constraints as it allows to slightly diverge from them. It is clear that in the limit of τ1,τ2→+∞→subscript𝜏1subscript𝜏2\tau_{1},\tau_{2}\rightarrow+\infty, we recover the “balanced” problem (Definition 3). This definition naturally also defines Unbalanced OT without regularization if ϵ=0italic-ϵ0\epsilon=0. The matching term would remain and the entropic one disappear.

Matching to the Closest  Another limit case is however particularly interesting in the quest for a unifying framework of the matching strategies. If the mass constraint is to be perfectly respected for the predictions (τ1→∞→subscript𝜏1\tau_{1}\rightarrow\infty), but not at all for the ground truth objects (τ2=0subscript𝜏20\tau_{2}=0), it suffices to assign the closest ground truth to each prediction. The same ground truth object could be assigned to multiple predictions and another could not be matched at all, not respecting the hard constraint for the ground truth 𝜷𝜷\bm{\beta}. Each prediction however is exactly assigned once, perfectly respecting the mass constraint for the predictions 𝜶𝜶\bm{\alpha}. By assigning a low enough value to the background, a prediction would be assigned to it provided all the other ground truth objects are further. In other words, the background cost would play the role of a threshold value.

Proposition 2 (Matching to the closest).

We consider the same objects as Proposition 1. In the limit of τ1→∞→subscript𝜏1\tau_{1}\rightarrow\infty and τ2=0subscript𝜏20\tau_{2}=0, Unbalanced OT (Definition 4) without regularization (ϵ=0italic-ϵ0\epsilon=0) admits as solution each prediction being matched to the closest ground truth object unless that distance is greater than a threshold value ℒmatch​(𝐲^i,𝐲Ng+1=∅)=c∅subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝐲𝑖subscript𝐲subscript𝑁𝑔1subscript𝑐\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{N_{g}+1}=\varnothing\right)=c_{\varnothing}. It is then matched to the background ∅\varnothing. In particular, we have

P^i,j={1Npif ​j=arg⁡minj⁣∈⁣⟦Ng+1⟧​{ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚j)},0otherwise.subscript^𝑃𝑖𝑗cases1subscript𝑁𝑝if 𝑗subscriptmin𝑗delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝑁𝑔1subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗0otherwise\hat{P}_{i,j}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\frac{1}{N_{p}}&\text{if }j=\mathrm{\arg\,min}_{j\in\llbracket N_{g}+1\rrbracket}\left\{\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right\},\\ 0&\text{otherwise}.\end{array}\right. (7)
Proof.

We refer to Appendix B.2. ∎

The converse also holds. If the ground truth objects mass constraints were to be perfectly respected (τ2→∞→subscript𝜏2\tau_{2}\rightarrow\infty), but not the predictions (τ1→0→subscript𝜏10\tau_{1}\rightarrow 0), each ground truth would then be matched to the closest prediction. The background would be matched to the remaining predictions. Some predictions could not be matched and other ones multiple times. The limits of Unbalanced OT are illustrated in Fig. 4. By setting the threshold sufficiently high, we get an exact minimum, i.e., where every prediction is matched to the closest ground truth. This can be observed in Figure 2(d).

Scaling Algorithm  Similarly as before, adding entropic regularization (ϵ≠0italic-ϵ0\epsilon\neq 0) to the Unbalanced OT allows it to be solved efficiently on GPU with a scaling algorithm, as an extension of Sinkhorn’s algorithm [chizat2018scaling, chizat-these]. The regularization still also allows for smoother matches, as shown in Figure 2(c).

Softmax  In the limit of τ1→+∞→subscript𝜏1\tau_{1}\rightarrow+\infty and τ2=0subscript𝜏20\tau_{2}=0, the solution corresponds to a softmax over the ground truth objects for each prediction. The regularization ε𝜀\varepsilon controls then the “softness” of the softmax, with ε=1𝜀1\varepsilon=1 corresponding to the conventional softmax and ε→0→𝜀0\varepsilon\rightarrow 0 the matching to the closest. We refer to Appendix C.2 for more information.

3 Matching

Following previous work [carion2020detr, zhu2020deformabledetr, ren2015fasterrcnn, redmon2016yolo, liu2016ssd], we define a multi-task matching cost between a prediction 𝒚^isubscript^𝒚𝑖\hat{\bm{y}}_{i} and a ground truth object 𝒚jsubscript𝒚𝑗\bm{y}_{j} as the composition of a classification loss ensuring that similar object classes are matched together and a localization loss ensuring the correspondence of the positions and shapes of the matched boxes ℒ​(𝒚^i,𝒚j)=ℒclassification​(𝒄^i,𝒄j)+ℒlocalization​(𝒃^i,𝒃j)ℒsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗subscriptℒclassificationsubscript^𝒄𝑖subscript𝒄𝑗subscriptℒlocalizationsubscript^𝒃𝑖subscript𝒃𝑗\mathcal{L}(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j})=\mathcal{L}_{\text{classification}}(\hat{\bm{c}}_{i},\bm{c}_{j})+\mathcal{L}_{\text{localization}}(\hat{\bm{b}}_{i},\bm{b}_{j}). Most models, however, do not use the same loss to determine the matches as the one used to train the model. We therefore refer to these two losses as ℒmatchsubscriptℒmatch\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}} and ℒtrainsubscriptℒtrain\mathcal{L}_{\text{train}}. The training procedure is the following: first find a match 𝑷^^𝑷\hat{\bm{P}} given a matching strategy and matching cost ℒmatchsubscriptℒmatch\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}, then compute the loss Np​∑i=1Np∑j=1NgP^i​j​ℒtrain​(𝒚^i,𝒚j)subscript𝑁𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑁𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑔subscript^𝑃𝑖𝑗subscriptℒtrainsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗N_{p}\sum_{i=1}^{N_{p}}\sum_{j=1}^{N_{g}}\hat{P}_{ij}\mathcal{L}_{\text{train}}(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}) where the particular training loss for the background ground truth includes only a classification term ℒtrain​(𝒚^i,∅)=ℒclassification​(𝒄^i,∅)subscriptℒtrainsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscriptℒclassificationsubscript^𝒄𝑖\mathcal{L}_{\text{train}}(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\varnothing)=\mathcal{L}_{\text{classification}}(\hat{\bm{c}}_{i},\varnothing).

3.1 Detection Transformer (DETR)

The object detection is performed by matching the predictions to the ground truth boxes with the Hungarian algorithm applied to the loss ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚j)=λprob​(1−⟨𝒄^i,𝒄j⟩)+λℓ1​∥𝒃^i−𝒃j∥1+λGIoU​(1−GIoU​(𝒃^i,𝒃j))subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗subscript𝜆prob1subscript^𝒄𝑖subscript𝒄𝑗subscript𝜆superscriptℓ1subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript^𝒃𝑖subscript𝒃𝑗1subscript𝜆GIoU1GIoUsubscript^𝒃𝑖subscript𝒃𝑗\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j})=\lambda_{\text{prob}}(1-\left<\hat{\bm{c}}_{i},\bm{c}_{j}\right>)+\lambda_{\ell^{1}}\lVert\hat{\bm{b}}_{i}-\bm{b}_{j}\rVert_{1}+\lambda_{\mathrm{GIoU}}(1-\mathrm{GIoU}(\hat{\bm{b}}_{i},\bm{b}_{j})) (Definition 2). To do so, the number of predictions and ground truth boxes must be of the same size. This is achieved by padding the ground truths with (Np−Ng)subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔(N_{p}-N_{g}) dummy background ∅\varnothing objects. Essentially, this is the same as what is developed in Proposition 1. The obtained match is then used to define an object-specific loss, where each matched prediction is pushed toward its corresponding ground truth object. The predictions that are not matched to a ground truth object are considered to be matched with the background and are pushed to predict the background class. The training loss uses the cross-entropy (CECE\mathrm{CE}) for classification: ℒtrain​(𝒚^i,𝒚j)=λCE​ℒCE​(𝒄^i,𝒄j)+λℓ1​∥𝒃^i−𝒃j∥1+λGIoU​(1−GIoU​(𝒃^i,𝒃j))subscriptℒtrainsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗subscript𝜆CEsubscriptℒCEsubscript^𝒄𝑖subscript𝒄𝑗subscript𝜆superscriptℓ1subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript^𝒃𝑖subscript𝒃𝑗1subscript𝜆GIoU1GIoUsubscript^𝒃𝑖subscript𝒃𝑗\mathcal{L}_{\text{train}}(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j})=\lambda_{\mathrm{CE}}\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{CE}}(\hat{\bm{c}}_{i},\bm{c}_{j})+\lambda_{\ell^{1}}\lVert\hat{\bm{b}}_{i}-\bm{b}_{j}\rVert_{1}+\lambda_{\mathrm{GIoU}}(1-\mathrm{GIoU}(\hat{\bm{b}}_{i},\bm{b}_{j})). By directly applying Proposition 1 and adding entropic regularization (Definition 3), we can use Sinkhorn’s algorithm and push each prediction 𝒚^isubscript^𝒚𝑖\hat{\bm{y}}_{i} to ground truth 𝒚jsubscript𝒚𝑗\bm{y}_{j} according to weight P^i,jsubscript^𝑃𝑖𝑗\hat{P}_{i,j}. In particular, for any non-zero P^i,Ng+1≠0subscript^𝑃𝑖subscript𝑁𝑔10\hat{P}_{i,N_{g}+1}\neq 0, the prediction 𝒚^isubscript^𝒚𝑖\hat{\bm{y}}_{i} is pushed toward the background 𝒚Ng+1=∅subscript𝒚subscript𝑁𝑔1\bm{y}_{N_{g}+1}=\varnothing with weight P^i,Ng+1subscript^𝑃𝑖subscript𝑁𝑔1\hat{P}_{i,N_{g}+1}.

3.2 Single Shot MultiBox Detector (SSD)

The Single Shot MultiBox Detector [liu2016ssd] uses a matching cost only comprised of the IoUIoU\mathrm{IoU} between the fixed anchor boxes 𝒃~isubscript~𝒃𝑖\tilde{\bm{b}}_{i} and the ground truth boxes: ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚j)=1−IoU​(𝒃~i,𝒃j)subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗1IoUsubscript~𝒃𝑖subscript𝒃𝑗\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j})=1-\mathrm{IoU}(\tilde{\bm{b}}_{i},\bm{b}_{j}) (the GIoUGIoU\mathrm{GIoU} was not published yet [giou]). Each ground truth is first matched toward the closest anchor box. Anchor boxes are then matched to a ground truth object if the matching cost is below a threshold of 0.5. In our framework, this corresponds to applying τ1=0subscript𝜏10\tau_{1}=0 and τ2→∞→subscript𝜏2\tau_{2}\to\infty for the first phase and then τ1→∞→subscript𝜏1\tau_{1}\to\infty and τ2=0subscript𝜏20\tau_{2}=0 with c∅=0.5subscript𝑐0.5c_{\varnothing}=0.5 (see Proposition 2). Here again, by adding entropic regularization (Definition 4), we can solve this using a scaling algorithm. We furthermore can play with the parameters τ1subscript𝜏1\tau_{1} and τ2subscript𝜏2\tau_{2} to make the matching tend slightly more towards a matching done with the Hungarian algorithm (Figure 2). Again, the training uses a different loss than the matching, in particular ℒtrain​(𝒚^i,𝒚j)=λCE​ℒCE​(𝒄^i,𝒄j)+λsmooth ​ℓ1​ℒsmooth ​ℓ1​(𝒃^i,𝒃j)subscriptℒtrainsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗subscript𝜆CEsubscriptℒCEsubscript^𝒄𝑖subscript𝒄𝑗subscript𝜆smooth superscriptℓ1subscriptℒsmooth superscriptℓ1subscript^𝒃𝑖subscript𝒃𝑗\mathcal{L}_{\text{train}}(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j})=\lambda_{\mathrm{CE}}\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{CE}}(\hat{\bm{c}}_{i},\bm{c}_{j})+\lambda_{\text{smooth }\ell^{1}}\mathcal{L}_{\text{smooth }\ell^{1}}(\hat{\bm{b}}_{i},\bm{b}_{j}).

Hard Negative Mining  Instead of using all negative examples Nneg=(Np−Ng)subscript𝑁negsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔N_{\text{neg}}=(N_{p}-N_{g}) (predictions matched to background), the method sorts them using the highest confidence loss ℒCE​(𝒄^i,∅)subscriptℒCEsubscript^𝒄𝑖\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{CE}}(\hat{\bm{c}}_{i},\varnothing) and picks the top ones so that the ratio between the hard negatives and positives Npos=Ngsubscript𝑁possubscript𝑁𝑔N_{\text{pos}}=N_{g} is at most 3 to 1. Since 𝑷^^𝑷\hat{\bm{P}} is non-binary, we define the number of negatives and positives to be the sum of the matches to the background Nneg=Np​∑i=1NpP^i,(Ng+1)subscript𝑁negsubscript𝑁𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑁𝑝subscript^𝑃𝑖subscript𝑁𝑔1N_{\text{neg}}=N_{p}\sum_{i=1}^{N_{p}}\hat{P}_{i,(N_{g}+1)} and to the ground truth objects Npos=Np​∑j=1Ng∑i=1NpP^i​jsubscript𝑁possubscript𝑁𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑁𝑝subscript^𝑃𝑖𝑗N_{\text{pos}}=N_{p}\sum_{j=1}^{N_{g}}\sum_{i=1}^{N_{p}}\hat{P}_{ij}. We verify that for any 𝑷∈𝒰​(𝜶,𝜷)𝑷𝒰𝜶𝜷\bm{P}\in\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta}), we have the same number of positives and negatives as the initial model: Nneg=(Np−Ng)subscript𝑁negsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔N_{\text{neg}}=(N_{p}-N_{g}) and Npos=Ngsubscript𝑁possubscript𝑁𝑔N_{\text{pos}}=N_{g}. Hence, hard negatives are the K𝐾K predictions with the highest confidence loss P^k,(Ng+1)​ℒCE​(𝒄^k,∅)subscript^𝑃𝑘subscript𝑁𝑔1subscriptℒCEsubscript^𝒄𝑘\hat{P}_{k,(N_{g}+1)}\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{CE}}(\hat{\bm{c}}_{k},\varnothing) such that the mass of kept negatives is at most triple the number of positives: Np​∑k=1KP^k,(Ng+1)s≤3​Npossubscript𝑁𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript^𝑃𝑘subscript𝑁𝑔1𝑠3subscript𝑁posN_{p}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\hat{P}_{k,(N_{g}+1)}^{s}\leq 3N_{\text{pos}}, where 𝑷^ssuperscript^𝑷𝑠\hat{\bm{P}}^{s} is a permutation of transport matrix 𝑷^^𝑷\hat{\bm{P}} with rows sorted by highest confidence loss.

4 Experimental Results & Discussion

We show that matching based on Unbalanced Optimal Transport generalizes many different matching strategies and performs on par with methods that use either Bipartite Matching or anchor boxes along with matching each prediction to the closest ground truth box with a threshold. We then analyze the influence of constraint parameter τ2subscript𝜏2\tau_{2} by training SSD with and without NMS for multiple parameter values. Finally, we show that OT with entropic regularization both improves the convergence and is faster to compute than the Hungarian algorithm in case of many matches.

4.1 Setup

Datasets  We perform experiments on a synthetic object detection dataset with 4.800 training and 960 validation images and on the large-scale COCO [lin2014microsoft] dataset with 118,287 training and 5,000 validation test images. We report on mean Average Precision (AP) and mean Average Recall (AR). The two metrics are an average of the per-class metrics following COCO’s official evaluation procedure. For the Color Boxes synthetic dataset, we uniformly randomly draw between 0 and 30 rectangles of 20 different colors from each image. Appendix I provides the detailed generation procedure and sample images.

Training  For a fair comparison, the classification and localization costs for matching and training are identical to the ones used by the models. Unless stated otherwise, we train the models with their default hyper-parameter sets. DETR and Deformable DETR are trained with hyper-parameters λprob=λCE=2subscript𝜆probsubscript𝜆CE2\lambda_{\text{prob}}=\lambda_{\mathrm{CE}}=2, λℓ1=5subscript𝜆superscriptℓ15\lambda_{\ell^{1}}=5 and λGIoU=2subscript𝜆GIoU2\lambda_{\mathrm{GIoU}}=2. For Deformable DETR, we found the classification cost to be overwhelmed by the localization costs in the regularized minimization problem (Definition 3). We therefore set λprob=5subscript𝜆prob5\lambda_{\text{prob}}=5. We, however keep λCE=2subscript𝜆CE2\lambda_{\mathrm{CE}}=2 so that the final loss value for a given matching remains unchanged. SSD is trained with original hyper-parameters λCE=λsmooth ​ℓ1=1subscript𝜆CEsubscript𝜆smooth superscriptℓ11\lambda_{\mathrm{CE}}=\lambda_{\text{smooth }\ell^{1}}=1. For OT, we set the entropic regularization to ϵ=ϵ0/(log⁡(2​Np)+1)italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ02subscript𝑁𝑝1\epsilon=\epsilon_{0}/(\log{(2N_{p})}+1) where ϵ0=0.12subscriptitalic-ϵ00.12\epsilon_{0}=0.12 for all models (App. D). In the following experiments, the Unbalanced OT is solved with multiple values of τ2subscript𝜏2\tau_{2} whereas τ1subscript𝜏1\tau_{1} is fixed to a large value τ1=100subscript𝜏1100\tau_{1}=100 to simulate a hard constraint. In practice, we limit the number of iterations of the scaling algorithm. This provides a good enough approximation [ge2021yolox].

4.2 Unified Matching Strategy

DETR and Deformable DETR  Convergence curves for DETR on the Color Boxes dataset are shown in Fig. 5 and associated metrics are presented in Table 1. DETR converges in half the number of epochs with the regularized balanced OT formulation. This confirms that one reason for slow DETR convergence is the discrete nature of BM, which is unstable, especially in the early stages of training. Training the model for more epochs with either BM or OT does not improve metrics as the model starts to overfit. Appendix E provides qualitative examples and a more detailed convergence analysis. We evaluate how these results translate to faster converging DETR-like models by additionally training Deformable DETR [zhu2020deformabledetr]. In addition to model improvements, Deformable DETR makes three times more predictions than DETR and uses a sigmoid focal loss [lin2017focalloss] instead of a softmax cross-entropy loss for both classification costs. Table 1 gives results on Color Boxes and COCO. We observe that the entropy term does not lead to faster convergence. Indeed, Deformable DETR converges in 505050 epochs with both matching strategies. Nevertheless, both OT and bipartite matching lead to similar AP and AR.

SSD and the Constraint Parameter  To better understand how unbalanced OT bridges the gap between DETR’s and SSD’s matching strategies, we analyze the variation in performance of SSD for different values of τ2subscript𝜏2\tau_{2}. Results for an initial learning rate of 0.0005 are displayed in Table 2. In the second row, the parameter value is close to zero. From Proposition 2 and when ϵ→0→italic-ϵ0\epsilon\to 0, each prediction is matched to the closest ground truth box unless the matching cost exceeds 0.5. Thus, multiple predictions are matched to each ground truth box, and NMS is needed to eliminate near duplicates. When NMS is removed, AP drops by 25.8 points and AR increases by 10.2 points. We observe similar results for the original SSD matching strategy (1st row), which suggests matching each ground truth box to the closest anchor box does not play a huge role in the two-stage matching procedure from SSD. The lower part of Table 1 shows the same for COCO. When τ2→+∞→subscript𝜏2\tau_{2}\to+\infty, one recovers the balanced formulation used in DETR (last row). Removing NMS leads to a 2.9 points drop for AP and a 9.7 points increase for AR. Depending on the field of application, it may be preferable to apply a matching strategy with a low τ2subscript𝜏2\tau_{2} and with NMS when precision is more important or without NMS when the recall is more important. Moreover, varying parameter τ2subscript𝜏2\tau_{2} offers more control on the matching strategy and therefore on the precision-recall trade-off [buckland1994precisionrecall].

Computation Time  For a relatively small number of predictions, implementations of Sinkhorn perform on par with the Hungarian algorithm (Fig. 6). The “balanced” algorithm is on average 2.6ms slower than the Hungarian algorithm for 100100100 predictions (DETR) and 1.5ms faster for 300 predictions (Deformable DETR). For more predictions, GPU parallelization of the Sinkhorn algorithm makes a large difference (more than 50x speedup). As a reference point, SSD300 and SSD512 make 8,73287328,732 and 24,5642456424,564 predictions.

5 Conclusion and Future Work

Throughout the paper, we showed both theoretically and experimentally how Unbalanced Optimal Transport unifies the Hungarian algorithm, matching each ground truth object to the best prediction and each prediction to the best ground truth, with or without threshold.

Experimentally, using OT and Unbalanced OT with entropic regularization is on par with the state-of-the-art for DETR, Deformable DETR and SSD. Moreover, we showed that entropic regularization lets DETR converge faster on the Color Boxes dataset and that parameter τ2subscript𝜏2\tau_{2} offers better control of the precision-recall trade-off. Finally, we showed that the scaling algorithms compute large numbers of matches faster than the Hungarian algorithm.

Limitations and Future Work  The convergence improvement of the regularized OT formulation compared to bipartite matching seems to hold only for DETR and on small-scale datasets. Further investigations may include Wasserstein-based matching costs for a further unification of the theory and the reduction of the entropy with time, as it seems to boost convergence only in early phases, but not in fine-tuning.

Unbalanced Optimal Transport: A Unified Framework for Object Detection
Supplementary Material

Appendix A Optimal Transport Discussion

The Otpimal Transport formulation presented throughout the paper is formulated in discrete space. In this section, we present the more general formulation of which the discrete one is a particular case of. We also discuss the Wasserstein distance in the particular context of object detection and the effect of regularization on the uniqueness of the solutions. Only the case of the original OT formulation—or “balanced” case—is covered here.

A.1 Continuous Formulation

More generally, we define Optimal Transport in its continuous form.

Definition 5 (Continuous Optimal Transport).

Given two distributions α∈𝒫+​(X)𝛼subscript𝒫𝑋\alpha\in\mathscr{P}_{+}(X) and β∈𝒫+​(Y)𝛽subscript𝒫𝑌\beta\in\mathscr{P}_{+}(Y) of same mass ∫α​dx=∫β​dy𝛼differential-d𝑥𝛽differential-d𝑦\int\alpha\,\mathrm{d}x=\int\beta\,\mathrm{d}y, and given an underlying cost function c:X×Y→[0,+∞]:𝑐→𝑋𝑌0c:X\times Y\rightarrow[0,+\infty], we define Continuous Optimal Transport as the minimization of a transport cost

inf{∫X×Yc​dγ:γ∈U​(α,β)},infimumconditional-setsubscript𝑋𝑌𝑐differential-d𝛾𝛾𝑈𝛼𝛽\inf\left\{\int_{X\times Y}c\,\mathrm{d}\gamma:\gamma\in U(\alpha,\beta)\right\}, (8)

with admissible solutions, here called transport plans

U​(α,β)={γ∈𝒫+​(X×Y):∫Ydγ=αand∫Xdγ=β}.𝑈𝛼𝛽conditional-set𝛾subscript𝒫𝑋𝑌formulae-sequencesubscript𝑌differential-d𝛾𝛼andsubscript𝑋differential-d𝛾𝛽U(\alpha,\beta)=\bigg{\{}\gamma\in\mathscr{P}_{+}(X\times Y):\int_{Y}\mathrm{d}\gamma=\alpha\quad\text{and}\quad\int_{X}\mathrm{d}\gamma=\beta\bigg{\}}. (9)

If a minimum exists, it is called the optimal transport plan γ^^𝛾\hat{\gamma}.

We replace the probability simplex ΔNsuperscriptΔ𝑁\Delta^{N} by the space on probability distributions 𝒫+​(X)subscript𝒫𝑋\mathscr{P}_{+}(X) on X𝑋X. The transport plans are the set of joint probability distribution γ∈𝒫+​(X×Y)𝛾subscript𝒫𝑋𝑌\gamma\in\mathscr{P}_{+}(X\times Y), whose marginal distributions are α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta. The discrete formulation (Definition 1) is a particular case where α=∑iαi​δ𝒚^i𝛼subscript𝑖subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝛿subscript^𝒚𝑖\alpha=\sum_{i}\alpha_{i}\delta_{\hat{\bm{y}}_{i}}, β=∑jβj​δ𝒚j𝛽subscript𝑗subscript𝛽𝑗subscript𝛿subscript𝒚𝑗\beta=\sum_{j}\beta_{j}\delta_{\bm{y}_{j}} and the cost c=ℒmatch𝑐subscriptℒmatchc=\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}. In this case, a minimum always exists.

A.2 Wasserstein Distance

This infimum defines a distance between α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta, called the Wasserstein distance 𝒲p​(α,β)subscript𝒲𝑝𝛼𝛽\mathcal{W}_{p}(\alpha,\beta), provided that the underlying cost function is also a distance c=dp𝑐superscript𝑑𝑝c=d^{p} up to some exponent p∈[1,+∞[p\in[1,+\infty[. In our case, ℒmatchsubscriptℒmatch\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}} is not a distance. More formally, sum of distances are distances. The ℓ1superscriptℓ1\ell^{1} norm is a distance, and 1−IoU1IoU1-\mathrm{IoU}, or 1−GIoU1GIoU1-\mathrm{GIoU} also are [giou]. However, the cross entropy or the focal loss do not satisfy the triangular inequality or the symmetry properties. In consequence, we cannot talk about a Wasserstein distance here.

Furthermore, interpreting a Wasserstein distance 𝒲p​(α,β)subscript𝒲𝑝𝛼𝛽\mathcal{W}_{p}(\alpha,\beta) would not make much sense even if the underlying matching cost was to be a distance. Indeed, the distributions α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta would be the same at every iteration in our framework. In other words, the distance would always be computed between the same points, but the underlying cost would change and it would be different for each image. Each iteration would be computing the distance of two same points in a changing geometry and each image would have its own evolving geometry.

For completeness, we must mention that the regularized version does not define a distance as 𝒲p,reg.​(𝜶,𝜶)=−ϵ​H​(𝑰Np,Np/Np)>0subscript𝒲𝑝reg.𝜶𝜶italic-ϵHsubscript𝑰subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑝0\mathcal{W}_{p,\text{reg.}}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\alpha})=-\epsilon\,\mathrm{H}(\bm{I}_{N_{p},N_{p}}/N_{p})>0 with 𝑰Np,Npsubscript𝑰subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑝\bm{I}_{N_{p},N_{p}} the identity matrix of size Npsubscript𝑁𝑝N_{p} (we refer to [genevay, genevay-these, sinkhorn-divergences] for a broader discussion on the subject).

A.3 Uniqueness

We consider here the discrete formulation used throughout the paper. By classical linear programming theory, the non-regularized problem admits a non-unique solution if and only if multiple extreme points minimize the problem. In that case, the set of minimizers is all the linear interpolations between those extreme points. The regularization term however is ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-strongly convex; the regularized problem thus always has a unique solution [peyre2019computational].

Appendix B Proofs of the Propositions

In this section, we provide the proofs of Propositions 1 and 2 and enrich them with some insight through a few additional results.

B.1 Hungarian Algorithm

Before providing a proof of the particular equivalence between OT and BM, we first consider a more general result.

Lemma 1.

We consider the rational probability simplex ΔℚN={𝐮∈ℚ≥0N|∑iui=1}superscriptsubscriptΔℚ𝑁conditional-set𝐮subscriptsuperscriptℚ𝑁absent0subscript𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖1\Delta_{\mathbb{Q}}^{N}=\{\bm{u}\in\mathbb{Q}^{N}_{\geq 0}|\sum_{i}u_{i}=1\}. Given an OT problem (Definition 1) with underlying distributions 𝛂∈ΔℚN𝛂subscriptsuperscriptΔ𝑁ℚ\bm{\alpha}\in\Delta^{N}_{\mathbb{Q}} and 𝛃∈ΔℚM𝛃subscriptsuperscriptΔ𝑀ℚ\bm{\beta}\in\Delta^{M}_{\mathbb{Q}}. Each extreme point of 𝒰​(𝛂,𝛃)𝒰𝛂𝛃\,\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta}) is comprised of elements, which are multiples of the common measure of 𝛂𝛂\bm{\alpha} and 𝛃𝛃\bm{\beta}:

𝑷 is an extreme point of 𝒰​(𝜶,𝜷)⟹𝑷∈CM​(𝜶,𝜷)⋅ℕ≥0N×M,𝑷 is an extreme point of 𝒰(𝜶,𝜷)⟹𝑷⋅CM𝜶𝜷superscriptsubscriptℕabsent0𝑁𝑀\text{$\bm{P}$ is an extreme point of $\,\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta})$}\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad\bm{P}\in\mathrm{CM}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta})\cdot\mathbb{N}_{\geq 0}^{N\times M}, (10)

where the common measure is the greatest rational such that all non-zero elements of both distributions are multiples of it:

CM​(𝜶,𝜷)=GCD​(LCM​([𝜶,𝜷])/[𝜶,𝜷])LCM​([𝜶,𝜷])∈ℚ>0,CM𝜶𝜷GCDLCM𝜶𝜷𝜶𝜷LCM𝜶𝜷subscriptℚabsent0\mathrm{CM}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta})=\frac{\mathrm{GCD}\left(\mathrm{LCM}\left(\left[\,\bm{\alpha},\,\bm{\beta}\,\right]\right)/\left[\,\bm{\alpha},\,\bm{\beta}\,\right]\right)}{\mathrm{LCM}\left(\left[\,\bm{\alpha},\,\bm{\beta}\,\right]\right)}\in\mathbb{Q}_{>0}, (11)

with GCD:ℕ>0N→ℕ>0:GCD→superscriptsubscriptℕabsent0𝑁subscriptℕabsent0\mathrm{GCD}:\mathbb{N}_{>0}^{N}\rightarrow\mathbb{N}_{>0} the greatest common divisor and LCM:ℕ>0N→ℕ>0:LCM→superscriptsubscriptℕabsent0𝑁subscriptℕabsent0\mathrm{LCM}:\mathbb{N}_{>0}^{N}\rightarrow\mathbb{N}_{>0} the lowest common multiple.

The common measure extends the GCDGCD\mathrm{GCD} to non-integers. As an example CM​([2/3,4/5])=2/15CM2345215\mathrm{CM}(\left[\,\nicefrac{{2}}{{3}},\,\nicefrac{{4}}{{5}}\,\right])=\nicefrac{{2}}{{15}} and CM​([2/3,5/6,4/7])=1/42CM235647142\mathrm{CM}(\left[\,\nicefrac{{2}}{{3}},\,\nicefrac{{5}}{{6}},\,\nicefrac{{4}}{{7}}\,\right])=\nicefrac{{1}}{{42}}.

Proof.

In [brualdi_2006], Corollary 8.1.3, an algorithm is given to build the exhaustive list of extreme points. It comprises only minimum and subtraction operations, which leave the common measure unchanged. ∎

Corollary 1.

Given the underlying distributions as in Proposition 1, the extreme points of 𝒰​(𝛂,𝛃)𝒰𝛂𝛃\,\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta}) are comprised only of zeros and 1/Np1subscript𝑁𝑝1/N_{p}:

𝑷 is an extreme point of 𝒰​(𝜶,𝜷)⟹𝑷∈{0,1/Np}Np×(Ng+1).𝑷 is an extreme point of 𝒰(𝜶,𝜷)⟹𝑷superscript01subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1\text{$\bm{P}$ is an extreme point of $\,\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta})$}\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad\bm{P}\in\left\{0,1/N_{p}\right\}^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)}. (12)

This is a direct consequence of Lemma 1 and the mass constraints directly implying that Pi≤1/Npsubscript𝑃𝑖1subscript𝑁𝑝P_{i}\leq 1/N_{p} for all i𝑖i. In this particular case, there is also an equivalence.

Lemma 2.

Given the underlying distributions as in Proposition 1, the extreme points of 𝒰​(𝛂,𝛃)𝒰𝛂𝛃\,\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta}) are comprised only of zeros and 1/Np1subscript𝑁𝑝1/N_{p}:

𝑷 is an extreme point of 𝒰​(𝜶,𝜷)⟺𝑷∈{0,1/Np}Np×(Ng+1)and𝑷∈𝒰​(𝜶,𝜷).formulae-sequence𝑷 is an extreme point of 𝒰(𝜶,𝜷)⟺𝑷superscript01subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1and𝑷𝒰𝜶𝜷\text{$\bm{P}$ is an extreme point of $\,\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta})$}\qquad\Longleftrightarrow\qquad\bm{P}\in\left\{0,1/N_{p}\right\}^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)}\quad\text{and}\quad\bm{P}\in\,\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta}). (13)
Proof.

We consider Corollary 1 and add the fact that such a match 𝑷∈{0,1/Np}Np×(Ng+1)𝑷superscript01subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1\bm{P}\in\left\{0,1/N_{p}\right\}^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)} only has one element per row (or prediction if we prefer) to satisfy the mass constraints. Therefore, it cannot be any interpolation of two other extreme points. ∎

We however also give a more direct proof, based essentially on the same arguments.

Proof.

We will first show that the elements of the match 𝑷𝑷\bm{P} corresponding to any extreme point, can only be 1/Np1subscript𝑁𝑝1/N_{p} or 00. Therefore we can consider the associated bipartite graph of the problem: each prediction consists in a node i𝑖i and each ground truth a node j𝑗j. Each non-zero value entry of 𝑷𝑷\bm{P} connects nodes i𝑖i and j𝑗j with weight Pi,jsubscript𝑃𝑖𝑗P_{i,j}. The solution is admissible if and only if the weight of each node i𝑖i equals αisubscript𝛼𝑖\alpha_{i} and j𝑗j equals βjsubscript𝛽𝑗\beta_{j}. A transport plan 𝑷𝑷\bm{P} is an extreme point if and only if the corresponding bipartite graph only consists in trees, or equivalently, it has no cycle (Theorem 8.1.2 of [brualdi_2006]).

Because the mass constraint must all sum up to one for the predictions, we already know that Pi,j≤1/Npsubscript𝑃𝑖𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑝P_{i,j}\leq 1/N_{p}. We will now proceed ad absurdum and suppose that there were to be an entry 0<Pi,j<1/Np0subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑝0<P_{i,j}<1/N_{p} connecting a prediction and a ground truth. In order to satisfy the mass constraints, they would both also have to be connected to another prediction and another ground truth. Similarly, these would also have to be connected to at least one prediction and one ground truth, and so on. They would all form a same graph, or be “linked” together in other words. By consequence, each new connection must be done to yet “unlinked” prediction and ground truth to avoid the formation of a cycle. Considering that there are Npsubscript𝑁𝑝N_{p} predictions, there would be at the end at least 2​Np2subscript𝑁𝑝2N_{p} edges within the graph. This is incompatible with the fact that there cannot be any cycle (Corollary 8.1.3 of [brualdi_2006]). By consequence, the entries of 𝑷𝑷\bm{P} must be either 00 or 1/Np1subscript𝑁𝑝1/N_{p}. ∎

We can now proceed to prove the said proposition.

Proposition 1.

The Hungarian algorithm with Npsubscript𝑁𝑝N_{p} predictions and Ng≤Npsubscript𝑁𝑔subscript𝑁𝑝N_{g}\leq N_{p} ground truth objects is a particular case of OT with 𝐏∈𝒰​(𝛂,𝛃)⊂ℝNp×(Ng+1)𝐏𝒰𝛂𝛃superscriptℝsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1\bm{P}\in\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta})\subset\mathbb{R}^{N_{p}\times(N_{g}+1)}, consisting of the predictions and the ground truth objects, with the background added {𝐲j}j=1Ng+1={𝐲j}j=1Ng∪(𝐲Ng+1=∅)superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐲𝑗𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑔1superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐲𝑗𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑔subscript𝐲subscript𝑁𝑔1\left\{\bm{y}_{j}\right\}_{j=1}^{N_{g}+1}=\left\{\bm{y}_{j}\right\}_{j=1}^{N_{g}}\cup\left(\bm{y}_{N_{g}+1}=\varnothing\right). The chosen underlying distributions are

𝜶𝜶\displaystyle\bm{\alpha} =\displaystyle= 1Np​[1, 1, 1,…, 1⏟Np predictions],1subscript𝑁𝑝delimited-[]subscript⏟111…1Np predictions\displaystyle\frac{1}{N_{p}}[\;\underbrace{1,\;1,\;1,\;\ldots,\;1}_{\text{$N_{p}$ predictions}}\;], (14)
𝜷𝜷\displaystyle\bm{\beta} =\displaystyle= 1Np​[1, 1,…, 1⏟Ng ground truth objects,(Np−Ng)⏟background ​∅],1subscript𝑁𝑝subscript⏟11…1Ng ground truth objectssubscript⏟subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔background \displaystyle\frac{1}{N_{p}}[\;\underbrace{1,\;1,\;\ldots,\;1}_{\text{$N_{g}$ ground truth objects}},\;\underbrace{(N_{p}-N_{g})}_{\text{background }\varnothing}\;], (15)

provided the background cost is constant: ℒmatch​(𝐲^i,∅)=c∅subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝐲𝑖subscript𝑐\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\varnothing\right)=c_{\varnothing}. In particular for j∈⟦Ng⟧j\in\llbracket N_{g}\rrbracket, we have σ^​(j)={i:Pi,j≠0}^𝜎𝑗conditional-set𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗0\hat{\sigma}(j)=\left\{i:P_{i,j}\neq 0\right\}, or equivalently σ^​(j)={i:Pi,j=1/Np}^𝜎𝑗conditional-set𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑝\hat{\sigma}(j)=\left\{i:P_{i,j}=1/N_{p}\right\}.

Proof.

We will demonstrate that OT with 𝜶=1Np​[ 1, 1, 1,…, 1]𝜶1subscript𝑁𝑝111…1\bm{\alpha}=\frac{1}{N_{p}}[\;1,\;1,\;1,\;\ldots,\;1\;] and 𝜷=1Np​[ 1, 1,…, 1,(Np−Ng)]𝜷1subscript𝑁𝑝11…1subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔\bm{\beta}=\frac{1}{N_{p}}[\;1,\;1,\;\ldots,\;1,\;(N_{p}-N_{g})\;] and constant background cost necessarily has the BM as minimal solution. We first observe that because of the linear nature of the problem, there is at least one extreme point that minimizes the total cost. By directly applying Lemma 2, there must be exactly one match per prediction and exactly one match for each non-background ground truth to satisfy the mass constraints. The added background ground truth has Np−Ngsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔N_{p}-N_{g} matches. This is equivalent to saying that disregarding the background ground truth, we wave σ∈𝒫Ng(⟦Np⟧)\sigma\in\mathcal{P}_{N_{g}}(\llbracket N_{p}\rrbracket) with σ^​(j)={i:Pi,j=1/Np}^𝜎𝑗conditional-set𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑝\hat{\sigma}(j)=\left\{i:P_{i,j}=1/N_{p}\right\}. The proof is concluded by observing that the part of the background in the total transport cost is equal to 1Np​(Np−Ng)​c∅1subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔subscript𝑐\frac{1}{N_{p}}\left(N_{p}-N_{g}\right)c_{\varnothing} and is constant, hence not influencing the minimum. ∎

B.2 Minimum Matching with Threshold

Proposition 2 (Matching to the closest).

We consider the same objects as Proposition 1. In the limit of τ1→∞→subscript𝜏1\tau_{1}\rightarrow\infty and τ2=0subscript𝜏20\tau_{2}=0, Unbalanced OT (Definition 4) without regularization (ϵ=0italic-ϵ0\epsilon=0) admits as solution each prediction being matched to the closest ground truth object unless that distance is greater than a threshold value ℒmatch​(𝐲^i,𝐲Ng+1=∅)=c∅subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝐲𝑖subscript𝐲subscript𝑁𝑔1subscript𝑐\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{N_{g}+1}=\varnothing\right)=c_{\varnothing}. It is then matched to the background ∅\varnothing. In particular, we have

P^i,j={1Npif ​j=arg⁡minj⁣∈⁣⟦Ng+1⟧​{ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚j)},0otherwise.subscript^𝑃𝑖𝑗cases1subscript𝑁𝑝if 𝑗subscriptmin𝑗delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝑁𝑔1subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗0otherwise\hat{P}_{i,j}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\frac{1}{N_{p}}&\text{if }j=\mathrm{\arg\,min}_{j\in\llbracket N_{g}+1\rrbracket}\left\{\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right\},\\ 0&\text{otherwise}.\end{array}\right. (16)
Proof.

By taking the limit of τ1→+∞→subscript𝜏1\tau_{1}\rightarrow+\infty and setting ϵ,τ2=0italic-ϵsubscript𝜏20\epsilon,\tau_{2}=0, the problem becomes

arg​min{∑i,j=1Np,Ng+1Pi,j​ℒmatch​(𝒚i,𝒚^j)|𝑷∈ℝ≥0Np×(Ng+1)},s.t.∑jPi,j=1/Np∀i.argminconditional-setsuperscriptsubscript𝑖𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗subscriptℒmatchsubscript𝒚𝑖subscript^𝒚𝑗𝑷superscriptsubscriptℝabsent0subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1s.t.subscript𝑗subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑝for-all𝑖\begin{array}[]{ll}\mathrm{arg\,min}&\left\{\left.\sum_{i,j=1}^{N_{p},N_{g}+1}P_{i,j}\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\bm{y}_{i},\hat{\bm{y}}_{j}\right)\right|\bm{P}\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)}\right\},\\ \text{s.t.}&\sum_{j}P_{i,j}=1/N_{p}\qquad\forall i.\end{array} (17)

We can now see that the choice made in each row is independent from the other rows. In other words, each ground truth object can be matched independently of the others. The minimization is then obtained if, for each prediction (or row), all the weight is put on the ground truth object with minimum cost, including the background. This leads to Eq. 16. ∎

Corollary 2 (Matching to the closest without threshold).

Provided the background cost is more expensive than any other cost c∅>max{ℒmatch(𝐲^i,𝐲j)|i∈⟦Np⟧andj∈⟦Ng⟧}c_{\varnothing}>\max\left.\big{\{}\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right|i\in\llbracket N_{p}\rrbracket\,\text{and}\,j\in\llbracket N_{g}\rrbracket\big{\}}, each prediction will always be matched to the closest ground truth.

In theory, this a much too strong condition, the background cost can just be greater than the minimum cost for each prediction ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,∅)>minj⁡{ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚j)}subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝑗subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\varnothing\right)>\min_{j}\left\{\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right\}. In practice, however, this does not change much. It suffices to set the background cost high enough and we are assured to get a minimum. One could also imagine a different background cost for each prediction in order to have a more granular threshold.

Appendix C Scaling Algorithms

We present here the two scaling algorithms: Sinkhorn’s algorithm for “‘balanced” Optimal Transport and its variant for Unbalanced Optimal Transport. We further show how it is connected to the softmax.

C.1 Sinkhorn and Variant

These two algorithms are taken from [peyre2019computational, chizat2018scaling]. In particular we can see how taking τ1→+∞→subscript𝜏1\tau_{1}\rightarrow+\infty and τ2→+∞→subscript𝜏2\tau_{2}\rightarrow+\infty in Algorithm 2 leads to Algorithm 1. Indeed, we have limτ→+∞ττ+ϵ=1subscript→𝜏𝜏𝜏italic-ϵ1\lim_{\tau\rightarrow+\infty}\frac{\tau}{\tau+\epsilon}=1. By ⊘⊘\oslash, we denote the element-wise (or Hadamard) division.

C.2 Connection with the Softmax

In this section, we lay a connection between the softmax and the solutions of the scaling algorithms, in particular considering its first iterations. We consider more precisely the softmin, which is the opposite of the softmax: (softmin​(𝒗))i=(softmax​(−𝒗))i=exp⁡(−vi)/∑j=1Nexp⁡(−vj)subscriptsoftmin𝒗𝑖subscriptsoftmax𝒗𝑖subscript𝑣𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscript𝑣𝑗\left(\mathrm{softmin}(\bm{v})\right)_{i}=\left(\mathrm{softmax}(-\bm{v})\right)_{i}=\exp(-v_{i})/\sum_{j=1}^{N}\exp(-v_{j}), for any vector 𝒗∈ℝN𝒗superscriptℝ𝑁\bm{v}\in\mathbb{R}^{N}. Considering a softmin over ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚j)subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right) is thus the same as considering the softmax over −ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚j)subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right), as in [loftr]. By simplicity, we will only use the softmax terminology.

C.2.1 Without Background

We first consider the case without background, where the underlying distributions are equal to 𝜶=𝟏Np/Np𝜶subscript1subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑝\bm{\alpha}=\bm{1}_{N_{p}}/N_{p} and 𝜷=𝟏Ng/Ng𝜷subscript1subscript𝑁𝑔subscript𝑁𝑔\bm{\beta}=\bm{1}_{N_{g}}/N_{g}. This does not correspond to the setup of Prop. 1 and only approximates a one-to-one match if Np=Ngsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔N_{p}=N_{g}.

Nevertheless, starting from both initial dual variables is more interesting in the “balanced” case.

The dual-softmax considered in [loftr] is essentially the same as Prop. 4, with the difference of a factor 222 in the numerator’s exponential:

Pi,jsubscript𝑃𝑖𝑗\displaystyle P_{i,j} =\displaystyle= softmax​([−ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚k)]k=1Ng)j⋅softmax​([−ℒmatch​(𝒚^l,𝒚j)]j=1Np)i,⋅softmaxsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑘𝑘1subscript𝑁𝑔𝑗softmaxsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑙subscript𝒚𝑗𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑝𝑖\displaystyle\mathrm{softmax}\left(\left[-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{k}\right)\right]_{k=1}^{N_{g}}\right)_{j}\cdot\,\mathrm{softmax}\left(\left[-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{l},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right]_{j=1}^{N_{p}}\right)_{i}, (24)
=\displaystyle= exp⁡(−2​ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚j))∑i=1Npexp⁡(−ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚j))⋅∑j=1Ngexp⁡(−ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚j)).2subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑁𝑝⋅subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑔subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗\displaystyle\frac{\exp\left(-2\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right)}{\sum_{i=1}^{N_{p}}\exp\left(-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right)\cdot\sum_{j=1}^{N_{g}}\exp\left(-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right)}. (25)

C.2.2 With Background

We now consider the underlying distributions as defined in Prop. 1. Fundamentally, adding a background with a different weight than the other ground truth objects does not change much. The unbalanced case with τ1→+∞→subscript𝜏1\tau_{1}\rightarrow+\infty and τ2=0subscript𝜏20\tau_{2}=0 remains exactly the same. The opposite case with τ1=0subscript𝜏10\tau_{1}=0 and τ2→+∞→subscript𝜏2\tau_{2}\rightarrow+\infty now becomes

P^i,j=1Np​exp⁡(−ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚j))∑i=1Npexp⁡(−ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚j)),subscript^𝑃𝑖𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑝subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑁𝑝subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗\hat{P}_{i,j}=\frac{1}{N_{p}}\frac{\exp\left(-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right)}{\sum_{i=1}^{N_{p}}\exp\left(-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right)}, (26)

for all 1≤j≤Ng1𝑗subscript𝑁𝑔1\leq j\leq N_{g}, and

P^i,j=Np−NgNp​exp⁡(−ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚j))∑i=1Npexp⁡(−ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚j)),subscript^𝑃𝑖𝑗subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔subscript𝑁𝑝subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑁𝑝subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗\hat{P}_{i,j}=\frac{N_{p}-N_{g}}{N_{p}}\frac{\exp\left(-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right)}{\sum_{i=1}^{N_{p}}\exp\left(-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right)}, (27)

for j=Ng+1𝑗subscript𝑁𝑔1j=N_{g}+1 (the background). In essence, this ensures that the mass constraints induced by τ2subscript𝜏2\tau_{2} are satisfied, as the background has a higher weight.

Similarly, the “balanced” case is the same as Eq. 21 for all 1≤j≤Ng1𝑗subscript𝑁𝑔1\leq j\leq N_{g}. For j=Ng+1𝑗subscript𝑁𝑔1j=N_{g}+1, we have the same with an added factor:

Pi,j=(Np−Ng)​exp⁡(−ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚j))∑i=1Npexp⁡(−ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚j))⋅∑j=1Ngexp⁡(−ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚j)).subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑁𝑝⋅subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑔subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗P_{i,j}=\left(N_{p}-N_{g}\right)\frac{\exp\left(-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right)}{\sum_{i=1}^{N_{p}}\exp\left(-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right)\cdot\sum_{j=1}^{N_{g}}\exp\left(-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right)}. (28)

C.2.3 Other Regularization

We can also consider other cases that having the regularization ε=1𝜀1\varepsilon=1. The regularization ε𝜀\varepsilon controls the “softness” of the softmax: the greater is ε𝜀\varepsilon, the softer is the minimum; the smaller, the harder. In the case of no regularization at all (ε→0→𝜀0\varepsilon\rightarrow 0), the softmax is exactly a minimum as proven in Prop. 2. This can be observed at Fig. 8.

Appendix D Scaling the Entropic Parameter

In this section, we consider the particular choice of the entropic regularization parameter. In particular, we study how it scales with the problem size.

D.1 Uniform Matches

Definition 6 (Matches).

We define a match 𝐏∈ℝ+Np×(Ng+1)𝐏superscriptsubscriptℝsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1\bm{P}\in\mathbb{R}_{+}^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)} as a positive matrix of unity mass ∑i,jPi,j=1subscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗1\sum_{i,j}P_{i,j}=1. The set of all matches of size Np×(Ng+1)subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right) is the joint probability simplex ΔNp×(Ng+1)superscriptΔsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1\Delta^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)}.

We now consider a particular subset of all these matches.

Definition 7 (Uniform Matches).

We define the set of uniform matches Δunif.Np×(Ng+1)⊊ΔNp×(Ng+1)subscriptsuperscriptΔsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1unifsuperscriptΔsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1\Delta^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)}_{\mathrm{unif.}}\subsetneq\Delta^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)} as the set of matrices 𝐏unif.∈Δunif.Np×(Ng+1)superscript𝐏unifsubscriptsuperscriptΔsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1unif\bm{P}^{\mathrm{unif.}}\in\Delta^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)}_{\mathrm{unif.}}, containing only zero elements and all non-zero elements having the same value:

Pi,junif.={0for some values,1/|spt​(𝑷unif.)|for the other values,superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑖𝑗unifcases0for some values,1sptsuperscript𝑷uniffor the other values,P_{i,j}^{\mathrm{unif.}}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}0&\text{for some values,}\\ 1/\left|\mathrm{spt}\left(\bm{P}^{\mathrm{unif.}}\right)\right|&\text{for the other values,}\end{array}\right. (29)

with the support spt:𝐏↦{(i,j):Pi,j≠0}:sptmaps-to𝐏conditional-set𝑖𝑗subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗0\mathrm{spt}:\bm{P}\mapsto\left\{(i,j):P_{i,j}\neq 0\right\} and |⋅|\left|\,\cdot\,\right| the cardinality of a set.

We directly see from the definition that the matrices are well defined as they have unity mass. They are uniquely defined by the carnality of their support.

Proposition 5 (Cardinality).

The cardinality of Δunif.Np×(Ng+1)subscriptsuperscriptΔsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1unif\Delta^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)}_{\mathrm{unif.}} is given by

|Δunif.Np×(Ng+1)|=2Np​(Ng+1).subscriptsuperscriptΔsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1unifsuperscript2subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1\left|\Delta^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)}_{\mathrm{unif.}}\right|=2^{N_{p}\left(N_{g}+1\right)}. (30)
Proof.

We first notice that the different possible supports k=spt⁡(𝑷unif.)𝑘sptsuperscript𝑷unifk=\operatorname{spt}\left(\bm{P}^{\mathrm{unif.}}\right) range from 1≤k≤Np​(Ng+1)1𝑘subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔11\leq k\leq N_{p}\left(N_{g}+1\right). For any support of size k𝑘k, we have to consider a uniform match containing all combinations. The rest follows from the binomial identity ∑k=1Np​(Ng+1)(Np​(Ng+1)k)=2Np​(Ng+1)superscriptsubscript𝑘1subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1binomialsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1𝑘superscript2subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1\sum_{k=1}^{N_{p}\left(N_{g}+1\right)}\binom{N_{p}\left(N_{g}+1\right)}{k}=2^{N_{p}\left(N_{g}+1\right)}. ∎

We can also see that the uniform matches cover the set of all matches.

Proposition 6 (Diameter).

The diameter of the set of transport matrices ΔNp×(Ng+1)superscriptΔsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1\Delta^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)} and uniform transport matrices Δunif.Np×(Ng+1)subscriptsuperscriptΔsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1unif\Delta^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)}_{\mathrm{unif.}}, equipped with the Fröbenius norm ∥⋅∥F\|\cdot\|_{F}, is given by

Maximizing the Fröbenius norm is equivalent to considering the maximization of ∑i(ui−vi)2subscript𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑣𝑖2\sum_{i}(u_{i}-v_{i})^{2} subject to ∑iui=1subscript𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖1\sum_{i}u_{i}=1 and ∑ivi=1subscript𝑖subscript𝑣𝑖1\sum_{i}v_{i}=1, with 𝒖,𝒗≥0𝒖𝒗0\bm{u},\bm{v}\geq 0. It takes its maximum value on the boundary of the admissible solutions, for ui=1subscript𝑢𝑖1u_{i}=1 (the rest is zero) and vj=1subscript𝑣𝑗1v_{j}=1 (the rest zero) for any j≠i𝑗𝑖j\neq i. These extreme points are also in Δunif.Np×(Ng+1)subscriptsuperscriptΔsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1unif\Delta^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)}_{\mathrm{unif.}}, in particular those of unity support spt⁡(𝑷unif.)=1sptsuperscript𝑷unif1\operatorname{spt}\left(\bm{P}^{\mathrm{unif.}}\right)=1. ∎

Corollary 3.

Proposition 8.

Proof.

We consider the distance between any element 𝑷∈ΔNp×(Ng+1)𝑷superscriptΔsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1\bm{P}\in\Delta^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)} and 𝑷unif.∈Δunif.Np×(Ng+1)superscript𝑷unifsubscriptsuperscriptΔsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1unif\bm{P}^{\mathrm{unif.}}\in\Delta^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)}_{\mathrm{unif.}}: ∥𝑷−𝑷unif.∥F2=∑i,j=1Np,(Ng+1)(Pi,j−Pi,junif.)2=∑i,j=1Np,(Ng+1)Pi,j2+(Pi,junif.)2−2​Pi​j​Pi,junif.superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑷superscript𝑷unif𝐹2superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑖𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑃unif𝑖𝑗2superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑖𝑗2superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑃unif𝑖𝑗22subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑃unif𝑖𝑗\lVert\bm{P}-\bm{P}^{\mathrm{unif.}}\rVert_{F}^{2}=\sum_{i,j=1}^{N_{p},\left(N_{g}+1\right)}\left(P_{i,j}-P^{\mathrm{unif.}}_{i,j}\right)^{2}=\sum_{i,j=1}^{N_{p},\left(N_{g}+1\right)}P_{i,j}^{2}+\left(P^{\mathrm{unif.}}_{i,j}\right)^{2}-2P_{ij}P^{\mathrm{unif.}}_{i,j}.
