D.2 Entropy

The study of uniform matches is relevant as they have an easy formulation for their entropy.

Definition 8 (Entropy).

The entropy H:ΔNp×(Ng+1)→ℝ≥0:H→superscriptΔsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1subscriptℝabsent0\mathrm{H}:\Delta^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} of a match 𝐏𝐏\bm{P} is given by

H​(𝑷)=def.−∑i,jPi,j​(log⁡(Pi,j)−1).superscriptdef.H𝑷subscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗1\mathrm{H}(\bm{P})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def.}}}{{=}}-\sum_{i,j}P_{i,j}\left(\log\left(P_{i,j}\right)-1\right). (37)

If one of the elements would be zero, i.e., Pi,j=0subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗0P_{i,j}=0, we consider Pi,j​log⁡(Pi,j−1)=0subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗10P_{i,j}\log\left(P_{i,j}-1\right)=0.

The latter condition ensures that the entropy is well defined. This choice is justified as it remains consistent with the limit. Some authors prefer another convention [peyre2019computational].

Lemma 3.

The entropy of a uniform match 𝐏unif.∈Δunif.Np×(Ng+1)superscript𝐏unifsubscriptsuperscriptΔsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1unif\bm{P}^{\mathrm{unif.}}\in\Delta^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)}_{\mathrm{unif.}} is given by

H​(𝑷unif.)=log⁡(|spt​(𝑷unif.)|)+1.Hsuperscript𝑷unifsptsuperscript𝑷unif1\mathrm{H}(\bm{P}^{\mathrm{unif.}})=\log\left(\left|\mathrm{spt}(\bm{P}^{\mathrm{unif.}})\right|\right)+1. (38)
Proof.

The proof is a direct application of the definition of the entropy:

H​(𝑷unif.)Hsuperscript𝑷unif\displaystyle\mathrm{H}(\bm{P}^{\mathrm{unif.}}) =\displaystyle= −∑i,jPi,junif.​(log⁡(Pi,junif.)−1),subscript𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑖𝑗unifsubscriptsuperscript𝑃unif𝑖𝑗1\displaystyle-\sum_{i,j}P_{i,j}^{\mathrm{unif.}}\left(\log\left(P^{\mathrm{unif.}}_{i,j}\right)-1\right), (39)
=\displaystyle= −∑spt⁡(𝑷unif.)Pi,junif.​(log⁡(Pi,junif.)−1),subscriptsptsuperscript𝑷unifsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑖𝑗unifsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑖𝑗unif1\displaystyle-\sum_{\operatorname{spt}\left(\bm{P}^{\mathrm{unif.}}\right)}P_{i,j}^{\mathrm{unif.}}\left(\log\left(P_{i,j}^{\mathrm{unif.}}\right)-1\right), (40)
=\displaystyle= −|spt​(𝑷unif.)||spt​(𝑷unif.)|​(log⁡(1|spt​(𝑷unif.)|)−1),sptsuperscript𝑷unifsptsuperscript𝑷unif1sptsuperscript𝑷unif1\displaystyle-\frac{\left|\mathrm{spt}\left(\bm{P}^{\mathrm{unif.}}\right)\right|}{\left|\mathrm{spt}\left(\bm{P}^{\mathrm{unif.}}\right)\right|}\left(\log\left(\frac{1}{\left|\mathrm{spt}\left(\bm{P}^{\mathrm{unif.}}\right)\right|}\right)-1\right), (41)
=\displaystyle= log⁡(|spt​(𝑷unif.)|)+1.sptsuperscript𝑷unif1\displaystyle\log\left(\left|\mathrm{spt}(\bm{P}^{\mathrm{unif.}})\right|\right)+1. (42)

∎

Proposition 9.

For any match 𝐏∈ΔNp×(Ng+1)𝐏superscriptΔsubscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1\bm{P}\in\Delta^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)},

1≤H​(𝑷)≤log⁡(Np​(Ng+1))+1.1𝐻𝑷subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔111\leq H(\bm{P})\leq\log(N_{p}\left(N_{g}+1\right))+1. (43)
Proof.

For an arbitrary coupling matrix, the entropy is always minimal if Pi,j=1subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗1P_{i,j}=1 for one element and all the others are zero. Similarly, the entropy is always for the uniform match Pi,j=1/|spt​(𝑷)|subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗1spt𝑷P_{i,j}=1/\left|\mathrm{spt}\left(\bm{P}\right)\right| for all i,j𝑖𝑗i,j, with |spt​(𝑷)|=Np×(Ng+1)spt𝑷subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1\left|\mathrm{spt}\left(\bm{P}\right)\right|=N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right). ∎

D.3 Rule of Thumb

We first consider two different matches of different dimensions 𝑷1∈ΔNp,1×(Ng,1+1)subscript𝑷1superscriptΔsubscript𝑁𝑝1subscript𝑁𝑔11\bm{P}_{1}\in\Delta^{N_{p,1}\times\left(N_{g,1}+1\right)} and 𝑷2∈ΔNp,2×(Ng,2+1)subscript𝑷2superscriptΔsubscript𝑁𝑝2subscript𝑁𝑔21\bm{P}_{2}\in\Delta^{N_{p,2}\times\left(N_{g,2}+1\right)}. In this case, the OT with regularization cost (Definition 3) is given by ∑i,j=1Np,(Ng+1)Pi,j​ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚j)−ϵ​H​(𝑷)superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗italic-ϵH𝑷\sum_{i,j=1}^{N_{p},\left(N_{g}+1\right)}P_{i,j}\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)-\epsilon\,\mathrm{H}(\bm{P}). The goal is to scale the regularization parameter ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon in such a way that the weight of the entropy is proportionally the same. Because of unit mass of any match, we could assume that the first term ∑i,j=1Np,(Ng+1)Pi,j​ℒmatch​(𝒚^i,𝒚j)superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑔1subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗subscriptℒmatchsubscript^𝒚𝑖subscript𝒚𝑗\sum_{i,j=1}^{N_{p},\left(N_{g}+1\right)}P_{i,j}\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right) is independent of Npsubscript𝑁𝑝N_{p} and Ngsubscript𝑁𝑔N_{g} in magnitude. We therefore have to guarantee that ϵ1​H​(𝑷1)=ϵ2​H​(𝑷2)subscriptitalic-ϵ1Hsubscript𝑷1subscriptitalic-ϵ2Hsubscript𝑷2\epsilon_{1}\mathrm{H}\left(\bm{P}_{1}\right)=\epsilon_{2}\mathrm{H}\left(\bm{P}_{2}\right). Given an already determined regularization value ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon_{1} for one of the two sizes, the other can be found with ϵ2=ϵ1​H​(𝑷1)/H​(𝑷2)subscriptitalic-ϵ2subscriptitalic-ϵ1Hsubscript𝑷1Hsubscript𝑷2\epsilon_{2}=\epsilon_{1}\mathrm{H}\left(\bm{P}_{1}\right)/\mathrm{H}\left(\bm{P}_{2}\right). In practice, however, the entropy is not trivial and we can rely on the projection onto the uniform matches

ϵ1=ϵ2​log⁡(|spt⁡(ℙ​(𝑷2))|)+1log⁡(|spt⁡(ℙ​(𝑷1))|)+1.subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ2sptℙsubscript𝑷21sptℙsubscript𝑷11\epsilon_{1}=\epsilon_{2}\frac{\log\left(\left|\operatorname{spt}\left(\mathbb{P}\left(\bm{P}_{2}\right)\right)\right|\right)+1}{\log\left(\left|\operatorname{spt}\left(\mathbb{P}\left(\bm{P}_{1}\right)\right)\right|\right)+1}. (44)

In the particular case of Proposition 1, we can use the approximation |spt⁡(ℙ​(𝑷))|=Npsptℙ𝑷subscript𝑁𝑝\left|\operatorname{spt}\left(\mathbb{P}\left(\bm{P}\right)\right)\right|=N_{p}, which gives

ϵ1=ϵ2​log⁡(Np,2)+1log⁡(Np,1)+1.subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ2subscript𝑁𝑝21subscript𝑁𝑝11\epsilon_{1}=\epsilon_{2}\frac{\log\left(N_{p,2}\right)+1}{\log\left(N_{p,1}\right)+1}. (45)

The idea is to determine the optimal value ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon_{1} on toy examples. By setting Np=Np,2subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑁𝑝2N_{p}=N_{p,2}, ϵ=ϵ2italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ2\epsilon=\epsilon_{2} and ϵ0=ϵ1​(log⁡(Np,1)+1)subscriptitalic-ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscript𝑁𝑝11\epsilon_{0}=\epsilon_{1}\left(\log\left(N_{p,1}\right)+1\right), we can use the simple scaling formula ϵ=ϵ0/(log⁡(Np)+1)italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ0subscript𝑁𝑝1\epsilon=\epsilon_{0}/\left(\log\left(N_{p}\right)+1\right). From our experiments, we determined ϵ0=0.12subscriptitalic-ϵ00.12\epsilon_{0}=0.12.

Appendix E Qualitative Analysis

This section provides qualitative examples (Figure 10 and Figure 11) of some matches, as well as a convergence analysis for DETR and Deformable DETR. We compare the losses and matches 𝑷𝑷\bm{P} of the two matching algorithms at different training epochs.

Figure 10 shows some assignments of the two matching algorithms for DETR on the Color Boxes dataset. We sample examples with few ground truth objects for readability. We only show predictions that are matched at least once with a background ∅\varnothing ground truth in three consecutive epochs. At the beginning of the training, the Bipartite Matching with the Hungarian algorithm assigns different predictions to the ground truth objects from one epoch to the other. As an example, the algorithm for image №630 assigns predictions {4,49}449\{4,49\}, {8,1}81\{8,1\} and then {99,1}991\{99,1\} to the ground-truth objects {A,B}𝐴𝐵\{A,B\} at epoch 25 to 27 (Figure 10(a)). The regularized OT match instead provides a smoother solution and is more consistent from one epoch to the other. Later in training, Figure 10(a) illustrates that the regularized OT matches are one-to-one and behave like the bipartite ones.

Figure 12 provides the loss curves for DETR on the Color Boxes dataset. The curves suggest that the cross-entropy loss term mainly drives the convergence speedup in the early training epochs. We don’t observe such speedups on COCO or with Deformable DETR (Figure 13). An explanation could be that the difference between DETR and Deformable DETR is due to the slower convergence of transformers (we also tried DETR with the focal loss from Deformable DETR without improvement). The difference between Color Boxes and COCO is difficult to isolate, but probably due to the wider class diversity in the latter.

Appendix F Number of Sinkhorn Iterations

Using a stopping criterion is not straightforward when solving a batch of matching problems. The scaling algorithm is therefore set to a fixed number of iterations. Figure 14 displays the results for different numbers of iterations. For the balanced OT with 300 predictions (Figure 14(a)), the AP increases only slightly when more than 10 iterations are performed. Furthermore, it is sufficient to run 1 iteration in terms of the AR. For the Unbalanced OT with 8,732 predictions (Figure 14(b)), the metrics are significantly lower when running for less than 5 iterations. Again, running more than 10 iterations only slightly improves the final performance. This fact is supported by Prop. 3, which shows that in the limit case where τ1=0subscript𝜏10\tau_{1}=0 and τ2→+∞→subscript𝜏2\tau_{2}\rightarrow+\infty, only one or two iterations are required for convergence (depending on the implementation).

Appendix G First Constraint Parameter

In this section, we analyze the effect of the prediction’s mass constraint parameter τ1subscript𝜏1\tau_{1}, while we fix parameter τ2subscript𝜏2\tau_{2} to a large value τ2=100subscript𝜏2100\tau_{2}=100 to simulate a hard constraint. Parameter τ1subscript𝜏1\tau_{1} controls the degree to which variations in the prediction masses are penalized. Each ground-truth object can be matched to the best prediction in the limit case τ2→+∞→subscript𝜏2\tau_{2}\to+\infty and τ1=0subscript𝜏10\tau_{1}=0. However, some predictions cannot be matched, and others multiple times. The results for SSD on Color Boxes are displayed in Table 3. Wa can therefore conclude that the first constraint parameter τ1subscript𝜏1\tau_{1} has a small influence on the metrics, both with and without NMS. Nevertheless, a higher performance is reached in the balanced case, i.e., when τ1→+∞→subscript𝜏1\tau_{1}\to+\infty.

Appendix H Timing Analysis for SSD

As can be seen in Table 4, OT-based matches improve the epoch time (forward pass, compute the match cost, matching algorithm, and backward pass; in blue) for SSD with the Hungarian algorithm by almost 50%. The difference is smaller for DETR and variants as the models are proportionally heavier and the number of predictions smaller.

Appendix I Color Boxes Dataset

This section provides a discussion of the Color Boxes synthetic dataset. It is split into 4,800 training and 960 validation images of 500 ×\times 400 pixels. Images have a gray background. We uniformly randomly draw between 0 and 30 rectangles of 20 different colors, which define the category of the rectangle. The dimension of the rectangles vary from 12 to 80 pixels and are uniformly randomly rotated. They are placed such that the IoUIoU\mathrm{IoU} between their bounding boxes is at most 0.250.250.25. A gaussian noise of mean 0 and standard deviation 0.05 is added to each pixel value independently. Sample images are drawn in Fig. 15.
